DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua Expels 20 U.S. Diplomats In Retaliation For Panama Incident
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega ordered 20 American diplomats to leave the country in retaliation for a search by U.S. troops of the Nicaraguan ambassador's residence in Panama. In a national radio broadcast late Friday, Ortega said he had given the U.S. diplomats 72 hours to leave the country. He also said he had ordered the U.S. mission to reduce its support staff from 320 people to 100. Many people who work at the embassy are Nicaraguan nationals. A Nicaraguan government source said there were about 35 accredited U.S. diplomatic personnel in Nicaragua. Attempts to reach U.S. Embassy officials by telephone were not immediately successful. Earlier Friday, Nicaraguan Ambassador Antenor Ferrey said U.S. troops surrounded his residence, ordered all personnel to evacuate and searched the premises for weapons. U.S. officials said they had no information on the incident. ``They acted arrogantly, like Rambos!'' Ortega said. ``We were at grave risk of a political-military clash with the United States, which has maintained an aggressive attitude against Latin American countries.'' Ferrey said he and nine other people waited outside the residence while about 30 American troops searched the building for about two hours. The soldiers seized five rifles that Ferrey said were there for self-defense. A U.S. Army colonel in charge of the operation later apologized and returned the rifles, Ferrey said. Nicaraguan government sources, who insisted on anonymity, said that Foreign Minister Miguel D'Escoto was conducting unspecified ``diplomatic contacts'' with U.S. charge d'affaires John Leonard, the foreign ministers of Spain and Mexico, and Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez. The sources said D'Escoto also contacted top officials at the United Nations and the Organization of American States, but the sources refused to give details concerning these contacts. Leonard is the top U.S. diplomat in Nicaragua. The United States has not had an ambassador to Managua since July 1988, when the leftist Sandinista government expelled Ambassador Richard Melton and seven other American diplomats to protest alleged American interference in an opposition rally in the city of Nandaime. The United States responded by expelling Nicaraguan Ambassador Carlos Tunnerman. Diplomatic tensions between the two countries increased after the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion of Panama and the overthrow of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The Sandinistas placed the armed forces on ``maximum alert'' after the invasion. American troops surrounded the Nicaraguan, Cuban and Libyan embassies in Panama City following speculation that pro-Noriega loyalists had sought refuge in the missions. Nicaragua responded by briefly positioning military units around the U.S. Embassy in Managua, then withdrew them. Earlier this week, the Sandinista government barred a State Department plane from making its monthly supply run to the U.S. Embassy in Managua. The aircraft normally carries mail, books and supplies for the embassy Px.
